reviewText:
The game was .... a disappointment. The only thing that improved in this game over the previous installement (Mask of Arcadius) were the visuals and voice actors. Everything else took a step back.

The higher production values, rather than enhancing the game, did nothing but limit it. Having played through the entirety, I can't help but feel that what the devs did was create a game based on how much voice acting and animation they could afford. The final product was made to fit the packaging, which is a terrible way to design a game.

As a result, we got something that was incredibly rushed and bland. There's been almost no improvement in gameplay. In fact, Liberation Day plays like a lightly modded version of the original. The mission count is low and unvaried. The original had a nicely fleshed out story that taught you a lot about the world and invested you in its characters. Liberation Day took all of that and turned it into a shiny, half-written screenplay with all your favorite characters shoehorned into whatever role the plot demanded. We learn absolutely nothing new about the world or its characters, who have become one dimensional tropes in service of a rushed game.

MoA relied only on simple sprites and backgrounds and it really shined because of that. The devs created as much content as they felt would serve the gameplay experience and story and we got something that was not only special, but FREE. Liberation Day flipped that around and ironically, all the money that Patreon supporters and buyers of Sunrider Academy poured into the company has only ruined the next installment by making the studio believe it should try to crank out a AAA production level game.

reviewText:
For background, I’ve purchased all three Sunrider games, I’ve played Mask of  Arcadius extensively and I’ve purchased Academy as a way to thank the developers as I really want to like them.

I’ve played this game to completion on Captain difficulty, I did not listen to all the voice acting but I read all the dialog.

This review is SPOILER FREE and applicable to V2.0.

TL:DR: This game has many minor flaws and a huge storyline related flaw, as such I find myself unable to recommend it.


Technical:

This game suffers greatly in the technical aspect, Love in Space was a team of people that have a lot of passion on Eroge and Japanese Anime culture in general, however, they lack a lot of the technical talent in game development (which makes their efforts on creating games even more commendable) and have to resort to using what is basically a heavily modified version of the Ren’Py engine, which was never designed to create TBS games, leading to several gameplay related bugs, severely limited graphics fidelity and etc.

The reliance of the Ren’Py engine is clearly showing and the unoptimised engine is really hurting and limiting on what the TBS portion of the game could have been, LD right now utilizes simple graphics and sprites to represent combat, with no animation whatsoever, the TBS genre is currently experiencing a revival, and what LD has to offer in the TBS department is simply lacking even when compared to other indie products such as The Banner Saga.


Misc (Sound, non-gameplay related systems):

This game have a lot of minor issues that would have been redeemable if there weren’t so many of them.

The original English voice actors did not return due to scheduling reasons with the developers, they’ve decided that it is easier to have Japanese VN voice actors instead because they have the connection and it would be more convenient. Changing voice actors is going to be a bad idea most of the time especially for sequels (somewhat forgivable for remakes, persona 4 golden comes to mind) as it breaks the players’ emersion. To add to that, the Japanese voices are simply subpar, a lot of the voices are bad even by dlsite/dmm doujin game standards, whilst this might be subjective, I invite the readers to look for youtube videos of the Japanese voices and judge for themselves.

LD offers a save import function from Mask of Arcadius, similar to the way that Mass Effect handles save transfers, this is a really great idea, that is if it actually works, the save importer is unfortunately really bugged and a lot of people are unable to make the save importer work. Thankfully LD also offers decision choices for MoA when starting a new game similar to how Dragon Age 2 handled it.

The UI within the VN portion of the game feels slick and modern, however, display bugs and slowdowns especially in the store page are pretty blatant, and this is again, clearly a product of using the Ren’Py engine.


Story (Spoiler Free):

Whilst people like to claim that stories could not be objectively bad, I have to disagree, without posting spoilers, I have to say that the single worst part about LD is the story despite the myriad of issues previously mentioned.

Let’s get the elephant out of the room, LD contains an extremely linear storyline, there is a forced romance that feels extremely rushed and there are not choices at all, even the illusion of choice is lacking. To add on top of that, the storyline itself is objectively bad, I will explain below without spoilers. Whilst I do not feel like resorting to petty insults, I would like to respectfully remind the writers and developers that VNs are supposed to contain choices in them, otherwise, they are just dynamic novels, and those need actually really good writing, music, voice acting, and execution to pull off (planetarian comes to mind).

In LD, the protagonist is the standard dumb MC that doesn’t know anything and frequently breaks character, he is literally no better than the generic harem MC in LD. This is very disappointing given that this was not the case in the previous games.

In addition to the lackluster MC, the entire story makes the player feels like that they are just in for the ride, the MC does not have any impact on the storyline at all, it feels like the MC is just following everyone around, the player simply cannot make any meaningful choices and the MC himself did not make any meaningful choices, the MC just feels dead.

The forced romance is very problematic, it is clear that the developers are favouring a certain character with reckless abandon due to personal preference, whilst I agree that developers maintaining their personal touch on a game is very important, I think that even the way that they handled the forced romance is bad, the entire thing feels very rushed, the MC and the romance partner were acting blatantly out of character and the worst part is, the romance simply does not seem to any anything of significance to the storyline, at that point, I have to wonder why don’t they just make the romance optional if they wish to really focus on that character and not do other romanceable characters.

The basic concept of the entire storyline is quite intriguing, it shows a lot of potential, however, the execution done by LiS’s writers is unfortunately really bad, characters frequently act out of character, the plot turns into a jumbled mess towards the end starting from the middle of the story, and the writers wrote themselves into corners on several occasions only to perform arsepulls or deus ex machinas to get themselves out of the corner. There are more subjectively bad writing but that could not be discussed in depth without spoilers so I will refrain from doing that.


Conclusion

The unfortunate fact is, the awfully written (no other way to put it) storyline is the large, rusting, final nail on the coffin on top of the myriad of bugs, voice problems, engine problems for Liberation Day, as such, I simply cannot recommend Liberation Day to anyone for any price and the experience is genuinely not enjoyable and feels like a disservice to the franchise as a whole. I play the game and I see so much potential with the universe and the general plot themes, I want to like the game but I simply cannot.

As a former patreon backer (paid $10 for beta access) and longtime fan of the series, I really cannot reccomend this game, at all.

The pretty production values and Japanese VA (what is wrong with English, I wonder? It's a beautiful language!) came at the expense of practically everything that made the previous Sunrider VNs (First Arrival and Mask of Arcadius) the gems they were.

The story is gutted, and railroad-linear whereas the previous VNs had multiple choices. People have mentioned the unsatisfying ending, but they've neglected to mention that it's unsatisfying not because of itself, but because of the atrocious pacing, forced romance, and hamfisted characterization that preceded it. For around $10 (price in my region, might be higher in yours!), you get around 3 hours total of storyline content (as in VN sections as opposed to fights). That's pretty much inexcusable.

As for the gameplay, it manages to be worse than previous iterations. QA apparently went out the window. Longtime fans know that the Ren'Py engine that Sunrider uses is pushed to its limits by the battle system, and so we can forgive the occasional slowdown. But Liberation Day was much worse than that in this department. Battles weren't just slow, they were basically slideshows. I have a 4th generation i5 on a kickass custom rig, by the way, so don't even start saying it could be my system. It isn't. These same molasses-slow battles were frequently interrupted by near-freezes and once even an outright crash. I cringed at that last bit, by the way, because it happened at the exact same spot (2nd or 3rd fight) it did for me in the beta version about a month ago.

In conclusion:

This game isn't worth the money. It's inferior in every way but production values to the previous Sunrider novels, and those things are not worth the problems they brought. Also, I'll repeat myself: Japanese VA. WHY? Half the draw of this series for me is that it's an original English VN, written competently in English. What did you accomplish kicking the previous girls to the curb and replacing them with Japanese VAs? Was the weeaboo fantasy of a fully voiced JP game worth gutting the game over?

I'm just really disappointed. I expect better for the next installment of the series, but I'm afraid that LiS may have shot themselves in the foot here and won't be able to recover without ending up with some serious egg on their faces.

This review is based upon the 2.0 version of the game. I have not played the 1.0 version.

So we return to the surprisingly competent space drama with crazy anime girls. How is the third installment? (Sunrider the free game is actually two games, not one). Well, I got to import my save Mass Effect style, for one, and it seemed to have roughly the same impact as the ME import from ME1 to ME2 did (I never played ME3. ♥♥♥♥ EA). Namely that there are numerous mentions of your past actions and perhaps some influence on the events of the plot, but essentially the core of the story is the same. Arguably the most important imported choice comes in the form of what you decided in the big final decision of MoA, which determines one of your anime girls appearance for the entire game, and perhaps what sort of emotional baggage lies under the surface for that character.

Anyway, Liberation Day (LD) is a noticeable step up from the previous games in terms of budget, with Japanese VA's, prettier art, and updates to the interface and combat system to make it look better. I did have 2 crashes, but that's probably just bugs that need fixing from a game that only recently came out. Good thing this game autosaves constantly.

Ok, enough dodging. Time to talk about the story that got this game so many negative reviews.

Again, i'll state I played 2.0, not 1.0. I don't know when the game originally ended, but considering the Japanese voices stop after a certain point, it is pretty easy for me to guess when. And yes, that is kind of a ♥♥♥♥ ending since so much is left unanswered in preparation for the sequel. The stuff that comes after that point does much to clear things up, as well as providing setup for what is to come next. So as for how it ended, i'd say the update which the devs speedily released as fast as they could once word of how mad people were about the 1.0 ending almost certainly helped.

As for the rest of the plot? A mix of predictable plot points that center heavily on jealousy and suspicion thanks to how the last game ended. There are still plenty of silly moments, but the plot is primarily serious and high-stakes as you prepare for, and then fight, the battle to liberate Cera. I'm not a fan of the forced romance with Chigara, especially since she isn't one of my favorites, but i'll forgive it (somewhat) thanks to LD's final act when everything gets turned upside down and predictability goes out the window. I was playing a silly anime girl game with some heavy plot elements when suddenly I found myself in something more like what GRRM would have done (though not as deep or well-written, obviously). Good thing i've gotten used to that sort of thing. XD

Still not on board with Claude or where the plot takes her, though the scene with Ava going through the Medical Clinic later in the game was hilarious.

So, how is LD? It's alright. Is it overpriced for it's length? Yes. Did the devs perhaps spend too much time on boosting the budget with VA's and better art when they should have spent more time making game content? Probably. Is it a bad game? I don't think so. Most importantly, do I want to know what happens next in the Sunrider series? Yes. The preview for the next game (whenever that shows up) sounds like things are about to get even more insane as new players enter the fray that could change everything. Things to come certainly are looking interesting, :o

Until next time!

EDIT: Just played the 3.0 Update that adds the [RE]turn storyline to the game. No battles to fight, but a good VN experience where the choices you make can lead to happiness... or dying horribly. Also it lets you follow story routes for most of the rest of the crew (Asaga, Ava, Sola, Icari, and a secret Claude ending). It's more good stuff. Best of all, it was a free DLC. It's addition not only lets you play a new story after you finish Liberation Day, but makes an already decent game even better. :D

I'm going to be painfully honest... the gameplay struck me as being fine overall, if not buggy at times. But bugs can be fixed.

Story issues... that's another thing.

If I'm honest, the start and ending felt fine to me - the issue was that they were painfully linier. Even having the same ending with minor variations to it would have been better then stripping out practically all the choice and thematic RPG elements that made the first two Sunrider games so enjoayble. It feels like there is an entire chapter, or maybe even two, that is missing between the end of the prolouge levels and the start of the Cera invasion - like the first few episodes and last few episodes of a series were just stapled together. Add to that the linier romance choices in a game that practically objectified having multiple girls in it, and it feels like this game made a massive failling narratively.

It has better production values and full Japanese VO's, but in all honesty it's not worth the trade-off of axing the wonderful story that had been developing. The VO's are great and all, but feels painfully like the majority of the budget went there instead of developing the story, and it really wasn't worth it for something that, let's face it, is pretty much just a gimic - Sunrider Academy felt like it got more love story/writing-wise then Liberation Day did.

Truthfully, it's not a 'Bad' game - but it is straightforward and certianly is dissipointing. If I were to put it in mecha-anime-fan terms, Liberation Day is to Sunrider what Gundam SEED Destiny is to Gundam SEED; it is a lackluster continuation when everything is said and done compared to what the prior had to offer, and I really do not think it's worth a 24.99 price tag (just 5$ shy of equaling Sunrider Academy's price) when it has barely a third of the story-content and an eighth of the actual choice oppertunities compared to Sunrider Academy.

It's not a horrid game, but I just cannot reccomend it - at least not at the current price. And for someone who's been a fan of the series since it was on Kickstarter, it really hurts me to say that.

V2.0 - THE ENDING HAS BEEN EXPANDED UPON AND IS NOW FAR BETTER (30-40 MINUTES MORE AFTERWARDS). I LIKED IT BEFORE BUT IT WAS A DIVISIVE PART OF THE GAME, EVEN I HAVE TO SAY IT'S A VAST IMPROVEMENT.

Ok, just to get it out there, I'm a big fan of the series and have played everything attributed to Love in Space so i'm going to be biased. That said, I was a little disappointed with some parts of this game though I still very much recommend it provided you've played it's predecessors. This review will probably be quite long, so bear with me, if you find this unhelpful please leave a comment to clarify your gripes and I can try to improve it. Otherwise i'll assume it's simple downvote spam because I liked the game lol

NEGATIVES:

- Short. Much shorter than the pricetag suggests at first but similar in length to the previous installments so that should really be no surprise to any buyers who have actually played the games. V2.0 adds some extra length to the end of the story, around 25-40 mins or so of dialogue which helps.

- Linear. Choices and dialogue options are incredibly restricted in this game to the point where there are somewhere in the ballpark of ~5 decisions to make in conversations. I'll come back to this later.
V2.0 adds more choices into the extra story at the end of the game, though they aren't particularly big choices it's nice to have them

- Cliché. Personally I am fine with clichés as long as they're done well, and I think this game succeeds at this. Some people will turn their nose up at it though, so it has to be mentioned.

- POTENTIAL SPOILER WITH NO SPECIFICS:  Weird forced romance despite previous decisions. Some of us are wholly not into the pairing that is embedded into the story, but it plays a role so i'm ok with it. Some people will be more irritated than me though.

- Feels.... Easier than MoA? Maybe it's the new systems for upgrades and equipment or the combat tweaks, but it felt easier than the previous games up until very late in. This might disappoint some. Draw Fire is particularly overpowered right now, though that may be addressed at some point.

- Spelling and grammatical errors. Eh who cares, it totals a massive 3-4 mistakes in my playthrough. Nothing particularly bad.

Ok enough of that depressing ♥♥♥♥ lets get to why I still love this game

POSITIVES:

- Imports your save from the previous games. Helps you feel like it's a direct continuation of your game, though as i've only done a playthrough and a half I haven't seen all the differences previous choices can make, will probably update this in future when It's more clear how much it affects the game

- Vast improvements to combat and combat animations. The jumps to closeups and clunky attack animation screens of the previous games are reduced or cut to make combat look and feel more fluid. Flak, shields and armour are much more visible than before making it easier to make decisions in battle

- Visual upgrades. This game looks amazing, pretty much every character and scene is fantastic and the in-cockpit screens are beautiful. The one exception being the admiral as always. His face reminds me of raisins and haunts me.

- Voice acting. Pretty much fully voiced, though only in japanese. This is FINE. People of course are complaining about it, and with V2.0 they added the ENG battle voices back into the game (same as the MoA voices) with an option to disable the Japanese story voiceover.

- Shop/Upgrade system overhaul. Two resources, one for buying equipment and one for upgrading your ryders and the sunrider. You can undo your upgrades at any time and reallocate the intel to other areas if you're having trouble with a specific thing. ( PLEASE DO THIS TO MAKE IT EASIER GUYS ) Soo much better than before.

- Free restoration patch to remove the censorship. It's pinned in the discussions by the dev, so be sure to get this straight away or you're not playing the full" game.

- GREAT story. Yes it's a little cliche

reviewText:
Loved Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius? Loved Sunrider Academy? Love RPG-style visual novels in general? Well move along, because this game isn't what you're looking for.  There are only 2 or 3 choices throughout the game and, when you do make them, all your choices (from MoA, as well, which is a small plus) just provide flavor text without affecting anything in the story.  You don't even get a ship screen like you did in MoA.

You're forced into a romance with one of the more boring girls,  just so her betrayal (via Alice) and death affect the protag more, though most players probably would've felt the shock and horror regardless , while Claude, Krysta, and Icari (best waifu) are all pushed to the wayside, and all interactions with Asaga and Ava are only there to provide jealousy.   Did you end up capturing Cosette? Well you never get to talk to her or try to persuade her to join you (though she'd obviously stab you in the back), as both her and L7NN are forgotten about fairly quickly.   Oh, and remember how in MoA you say a bunch of nice things to Sola and she starts falling for you? Well forget about that, now she's an emotionless drone who does nothing but observe Asaga.

Aside from a few marked improvements in gameplay and art style which have been mentioned in other reviews, Sunrider: Liberation Day is just lazy and seems to only exist to put money into the pocket of the developer.  For the most part, it's a copy-paste of MoA with a few new units, and an altered (not upgraded) store/research system.  I honestly feel bad for those who supported this game on Patreon, because it feels like the developer just took all that Patreon money so he could take a trip to Japan and justify it with unneeded Japanese voice-acting.  I've seen a lot of backers leave since the release of this game, which I'm assuming are due to the fact that next to none of the expectations were met, so the next installment (oh yeah, it ends with a to be continued") will probably be worse than Liberation Day if it even gets made.

So to take away from this and other reviews
date: unless the game is heavily discounted or you can burn money
recommended: just wait for someone to do a "Let's Play" of it
hoursPlayed: because it'll be pretty much the same experience."

reviewText:
Love in space has demonstrated something we don't often see on steam. Developers learning from their mistakes, and community interaction. The game had so many issues at launch. Where were the choices? why didn't we have a star map anymore? why didn't we have a ship map anymore? What the heck was that ending supposed to be? Luckily, the Devs took note of these issues and the game's mixed reviews of about 50%. Now with the 2.0 patch, restoring missing content and fixing issues, the games has a positive score of about 70%. Amazing. but the game is nowhere near perfect, you can't simply patch out the main story, but Love in Space, unlike others, made an effort. So without further praise, it is my pleasure to announce my review of....

Sunrider: Liberation Day
What kind of game is this? How do you play? What do you do?
Sunrider: LD is a tactical turn-based game set in space. It is a direct sequel to Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius, preciously released on steam for free. It is also a visual novel. The story is told in a VN style outside of battles. It has heavy focus on story telling with fire emblem style battles. Your goal is to avenge your home planet of Cera after the tragic events of the 1st game.

Controls
The game is controlled entirely with the mouse.  Unless you intend to do some tinkering in the game's console, cheater.  It controls just fine. 10/10

Sound
The game sounds great. Fantastic OST, with loads of voice acting. On top of that, the 2.0 patch brings back the old English voice actors from the 1st game. The theme song by Iced Blade is sold as DLC for a rather high price, but it retains the quality of everything listed. 10/10

Graphics
The game looks great. There are no 3D models, but that doesn’t hold it back at all. All 2D sprites are well crafted and look fantastic in HD. The OP and Vanguard cut scenes are well animated, as well as the combat animations. However, there is a slight lack of said cut scenes. I understand the development cost, and the fact that this is a visual novel, but it felt a bit empty to me. A return of the old battle cut scenes would be nice as well, for those of us who had a PC that could run them. 8.5/10

Difficulty
The game's difficulty is completely up to you. Want to die forever? set it to the hardest mode. Just want the story? Set it to waifu mode. It fits almost every player, no matter what skill level. I found myself playing through on normal, and I still had to retry a few times, and I’m okay with that. 10/10

Story
Probably where the game struggles most. You made your calls in the 1st game, and sure, it may alter the course of the game a little bit, but that’s the issue, a little bit. The biggest complaint about this game is the lack of choose-able routes for girls. No matter what you do, you will be forced into a route with 1 girl. The game has 8 female characters, but you have no call over who is your favorite. The 1.0 ending was confusing, but the 2.0 engine fixed it. Sadly, it could not fix other things that had already been done 5/10

Performance
This game is a visual novel. it should run on a potato, right? No, you’re going to need 3gigs of ram and in I3 according to the specs. Why? because they're getting a turn-based strategy to run on a visual novel engine. Is this impressive? Yes! Is this how it should be programed? Probably not. Forgive me if I have no idea what I’m saying, perhaps I don’t understand. But I feel like the specs are way too high for a game with no 3d models. 4/10

OverallAs I said Sunrider LD is not a perfect game, but it is one that is worth the time the developers put into it. I can’t recommend you but it at is full price, as the story is too short, but it is a game that deserves to be played. If you haven’t already, I recommend you play the 1st Sunrider, and see what you think. I wish I could give this game a higher score, but it’s just not up to it. However, the story is not over, there will be a 4th installment to the series, and I expect nothing but greatness from the love in space development team

7.5/10 - Recommended

I quite liked Mask of Arcadius and was excited to play this game. Unfortunately it was a very different experince but not all change is bad so let's discuss the improvments of Liberation Day:

-The art is better
-The UI is easier to read
-The overlong combat animations are gone

Those are the improvments. Now let's take a look at all the ways this game has changed for the worse compared to its predecessor.
First and most suprisingly: this game runs like ♥♥♥♥. Strange for a visual novel with some strategy combat and less animations than the first game. Strange for this to be a problem on a PC that can run The Witcher 3 on rather high settings without problems. And it is strage that it is so bad that the stutering actually made me select the wrong options multiple times because the game couldn't keep up with my mouse. This is just unacceptable.

Secondly the lenght. By all accounts this game is way shorter than Mask of Arcadius (which was free), there are plenty of games for half the price of this one that will give you many times the value.

And finally my biggest problem: linearity. Mask of Arcadius had quite a few choices. Such as simple dialoge options, who to talk to between missions, what missions to take and even a few moral dilemmas that took quite some time for me to decide on. Nothing of the sort here. There are hardly any dialoge options, you do all missions in a set order and there is mabey one choice that affects the story.

To close this little review I wish to ask an open question for any passing Einstien to answer: Why in the name of all that is holy would you write a cast consisting almost exclusively of cute anime girls and then force the player to romance the most boring one? It boggles the mind!

I have a lot of thinking to do. In short: unless you are a millionaire you probaly have better things to spend your money on. Give it a miss.

Whelp, that was a fun ride. Quite a bit has changed from MoA and after playing through what is apparently now known as 1.0 (2.0 being a planned update that will rehash the story ending and bring back some lost MoA features) I can safely say that as a strategy RPG title, Sunrider stands loud and proud.

Our hull is holding! - The Great:

- Alot of MoA's clearly specialised ryder craft didn't actually have alot of specialization behind them apart from raw stats. LD changes this a bit by giving your units a few upgraded and a few more completely new abilities that really set them apart from each other. Where as in MoA it didn't reeeeaaaalllly bother me if a unit was knocked out of action, now in LD I can really feel the set back as I lose an entire front of strong counters for my recklessness in the form of a single loss.

- The cinematic value of LD has spiked unbelievably so in comparison to its past entry, which as far as Visual Novels go, was pretty darn cinematic and gripping (if at times rushed) in its own way. The Sunrider and her crew have really come to life here in the story sequences.

- Complementing LD's cinematic spike is all new art that cures the majority of same-face syndrome from MoA.

- Dat soundtrack. A good portion reused from MoA, but that's not a bad thing.

- XO Crescentia has taken the liberty of automatically declining any and all escort missions. Good on you commander.

Our hull is beginning to fracture! The Good:

- As mentioned above, your units are each altered a bit in how they function in LD, and since a single loss can feel potentially feel monumental, this also leads to rage and confusion moments when such units are lost to the overwhelming odds you face in this game. The Sunrider's captain must be of sound tactical mind to get anywhere. At all.

- Command points have been redesigned to be less blatantly spammable, with a hard cap of 4000. (5000 with the upgrade) Vanguard uses all 4000 points, so it really feels like your ultimate gambit and the dramatic sequence that plays everytime you use it cements that.

- All mini battle scenes that played out in MoA whenever a unit took an action besides movement have been cut out of LD. At first this struck me as a disasterous cut, but then I remembered just how unbelievably laggy MoA could be at times, largely due to the demand those scenes put on the struggling game engine. Small on board animations now play out for actions taken. The frame and responsiveness improvement is monumental and will help most anyone that might have missed the scenes to get over it. Overall, a step in the right direction in my opinion.

Sections 32, 60, and 2 have been compromised! - The Mixed

- You have pretty much no choices to make in LD. On the other hand LD does a decent job of playing off choices you made during MoA. I get the feeling of the same approach Muv-Luv Alternative took, where as the series went on, the actual choices you made and how much they mattered became less and less due to the odds the protagonist faced. The concept can be said to be the same here, but it isn't pulled off nearly as well. Some situations can be so utterly nonsensical that it will break your story immersion in favor of facepalm spam.

- The ship map is gone. (For 1.0 at least. Apparently to return in 2.0 update) The map vanishing felt like a big loss to me at first, but then I got to thinking, even if the ship map was still here, what would that change? I would still run through every scene, every side mission, and I'm still getting to R&D just fine. The only thing that changed would be the feeling of Kayto moving through the ship wherever you clicked to trigger the scenes being shown. An interesting change of psyche over something so simple.

Hull breaches on Deck 0! - The Bad

- Despite attempts to solve the problem, battle lag is still the Sunrider's greatest nemesis. It can get to old MoA levels of rapid clicking to hasten turns accidentally giving units bad orders.

- The story is all over the place. Everything done and timed just right in some places and then completely wat in others.

- You still don't see or care about any of the Sunrider's other crew. A wasted opportunity, but understandably skipped in the face of so much more content that would have to be made for them in order to do it well.

- Do you prefer English dubbed voices? Yes? WELL THEN TOO BAD! (To be addressed for battle scenes in 2.0)

Our systems are catastrophically failing one after another! - The Really Bad

- Who wrote those ending plot twists? Seriously? For what possible reason?

- At times the balancing can feel way off, when in actuality everything is working in a fair manner. Just not for you.

- This one is more just me, but I remember way more high percentage misses and low percentage hits than normal. The latter half of LD saw me not having faith in whatever numbers the game saw fit to show me for shot calculations. For a turn based strategy, these numbers are all this game has in the end.

Reccommend we abandon ship! - Whhhhhyyyyyy???????

- By now it's no mystery. Dat ending and those final scenes that lead up to it are just plain stupid. There was no reason to do that beyond creating potential sequel (or prequel) bait. It does a good job of making you feel like you wasted your time.

The Sunrider is at your command - The Verdict

- Well, the good and the bad wrap up nicely enough. As long as you ignore certain story developments, wasted characters and potential, and head cannon your way through the stupid, Liberation Day is a great game to own and play.

FREE DLC INCOMING, GET HYPED PEOPLE!!  (That being said, it might be a good idea to wait for it if you haven't bought the game.)

Here's the link to the dlc announcement: http://sunrider-vn.com/sunrider-liberation-day-return-announced/?age-verified=0cee2757c0

Even though I'm pretty excited to get what's basically a free game, I will say that [RE]turn sounds like a really dumb name. Hopefully the sequel won't get changed to [RE]birth. Now, onto the actual review:

As a fan of the previous games (which are free, if you haven't played it yet then get to it), this game is a 10/10 for me. I  really like the v1.0 release, although many people did not. The v2.0 made a few fixes to the gameplay and extended the ending. However, I really loved the 1.0 ending and would reccommend playing that one first, then installing 2.0 to see the extended ending. I'll give some general pro/cons and then some spoiler-free details about the two different versions.

CONS

- Poor optimization. I've heard that Renpy is a bad engine and in my experience makes my cpu run at mach 10. I've also heard that pretty much every VN uses this engine, so we'll just have to keep dealing with it I suppose.

- There are no choices in this game. Like, at all. There is a single, mostly meaningless choice Only in the 2.0 extended ending are there choices like there were in the previous games.

- Forced romance route. I thought it was a very good route that served the story well, but I understand a lot of people play this as a waifu game, and in this category it's lacking. If this was the main draw of the game for you consider getting it on sale.

- Side missions are both required and rather dull. Not a huge complaint, but the side missions felt like filler and lacked the humor of the filler missions in past games. (looking at you, escort mission from hell)

- Quite a bit shorter than the other sunriders, probably 5-6 hours. The additional ending adds an hour or so. (My own playtime is off because I played it before buying on steam)

- I think the game is best experienced by playing 1.0 first, then the expanded ending. Inconveniently, the saves are incompatible and you will need to rush through on easiest difficulty. (It didn't take me that long, be sure to hold down ctrl for the skip button)

PROS

+ Fantastic story. This is the best one so far, and it more than makes up for the things I listed as cons, such as the short length, lack of choices, and routes. If you liked the end of MoA, this one is even better.

+ INTENSE story. The marketing for this game made it pretty clear that you would be betrayed, and the game didn't disappoint.

+ Significantly prettier. Looks better in every way. The characters, backgrounds, and UI have all gotten a lot of love.

+ More improvements to the gameplay. One notable change is the command points, which are now capped at 4000, upgradable to 5000. Rather than hoarding your points to pull levers, you will regularly use it in combat, and it gets a boost from every non-vanguard kill (during the mission instead of after).

+ Voiced, in Japanese. I just disabled voices, so this didn't add anything for me.

+ Gorgeous soundtrack, but you knew that already. There's a new vanguard cannon song (that's longer than 45s!!!) and a very good OP, and I think a couple other background tracks.

+ I am expecting there continued dev support, because they've done so for MoA, which recieved an upadte, and Academy, which was on early access. They've responded to their somewhat negative feedback by releasing 2.0, and may do more in the future. (Updated: They ABSOLUTELY will be doing more in the future, in case you didn't notice the bold text at the top. According to the link, it's going to be twice as long, and will feature life-or-death choices and several routes. Notably lacking is a Chigara route, this might be because of spoiler reasons or just something they didn't mention. It won't be voiced either, but I don't care because I don't speak Japanese.)

Now, onto the different versions. The game, as of the time I installed it, 3/12, will default to v1.0. I would recommend you leave it at that at first. To opt in to v2.0, right click on the game and go to properties, then the beta tab. There is a drop down menu with two choices. Here is the changelog: http://steamcommunity.com/app/358750/discussions/0/405694115198117174/

v1.0:

+ I'm pretty sure that this is the ending as it was intended. The other one is good, for sure, but I think it was scrapped to become the beginning of Sunrider 4.

+ There is a rather simple but fairly major change in the story pacing prior to the ending in v2.0. It took away some of the dramatic effect that was in 1.0. This is one of the main reasons that I recommend v1.0 first.

+ The point I'm trying to back in the above is that v2.0 is slightly more accessible at the cost of the story being a bit more hand-holdy. It explains things that could be inferred, and generally makes it clear that it is setting up the next game. Some people were confused or unsure about if there would be a sequel and wanted more to the ending, and to me 2.0 feels like it was released as a response to that, because, in part, it was. It's not a BAD ending, I just don't think it's the BEST ending. It's like an epilogue tacked on to a great story.

+ You can still play 2.0 afterwards.

v2.0:

+ You get the whole story in a single playthrough, which will save around an hour of your time. 1.0 does not have the extended ending and  If a future release is compatible with 1.0 saves, or you wanted to replay it anyway, this is a non-issue, however as it stands you need to suffer the inconveinence of skipping through every battle. It's pretty easy to rush through the game on easy (you don't even need to buy upgrades, really), but it takes upwards of an hour. Hold down ctrl the whole time and it's not too bad.

+ A couple aesthetic changes that bring back some of the good from the past games, taken from the changelog: - Ship map restored (that blueprint of the Sunrider where crewmates faces pop up) - Galaxy map restored (however this doesn't matter much since side quests are required. The weak side quests are just paced SLIGHTLY better this way) - Battle voices from MoA can now be turned on (rather than only having Japanese battle voices or no voices)

- And of course, the ending. It's a good ending, but I think it works better if it's viewed as an extension to the original ending, that sort of bridges the gap between Liberation Day and Sunrider 4. It has a lot of very good stuff in it, it just doesn't conclusively end the game as well as 1.0 did. I would strongly recommend playing it, but wait until after finishing the first playthrough because 1.0 is such a strong ending.

I'll probably update this again once the dlc is out, because why the hell not. I like these games.

EDIT: http://steamcommunity.com/games/358750/announcements/detail/955133181078409337 The devs have come out with v2.0, which has more story content, as well as various other fixes. More routes will also be added later on, so thankfully, the devs are responding to criticism and working to improve their game. I highly suggest waiting to buy the game until all new updates come out, because as it is right now, the game is not completed. There IS a good amount of story content right now, so if you're a fan of the series, I suggest trying out what's currently available. However, if you haven't even played the original, I suggest waiting until this game is completely finished, and then do the original, and then this one.

v2.0Here is my quick re-review for the v2.0 content:

The later story content (late-game and v2.0) is AMAZING. I really look forward to the continuation of the story. There are so many plot twists, I was on the edge of my seat most of the time. It really plays with your emotions, and makes up for the somewhat predicatable story near the beginning of the game. I thought things were going to play out in a cliche way, but it turned out WAY better than I expected. However, the overall game is still relatively short, has a forced romance, hardly any side quests, etc. as people always complain about. I won't deny that. I believe these will all be fixed in future updates. This one update MAJORLY improves the game, and I sincerely hope that Samu-kun will continue to provide great content for this game. With the way the ending was set up (I will avoid spoilers) I believe that additional romances will open up in the game, as well as many new options for improvements. With what was foreshadowed for the future, there's an infinite amount of possibilities. I hope Samu-kun / Love in Space will milk this opportunity and add more content to THIS game, since the content that was supposedly for the next game has already been added in this v2.0 update. If, and I say *IF* there is a significant amount of content coming out as an update, I will say it's acceptable for it to come out as say, a $5 DLC for this game. On top of which, it's already a hassle to import the save from the original Sunrider, so having to do it again for another sequel would be a pain. Another good option would be to release new content as episodes.

All in all, I was really impressed with the content, despite all the mixed reviews. My only real disappointments were:
- Choices not mattering all that much (even if you import your save, a lot of the old choices don't make much of a different in this game since they aren't really referenced... I think a lot of them will come into play in future content, though)
- Battle maps being extremely laggy at times, and battles themselves being overly hard (I was able to play on Captain difficulty for a couple battles before it became overly hard, maybe I'm just bad?) Battles are still a ton of fun though, and the Vanguard Cannon animation is BADASS. The game could be a lot better if more awesome animations were added.
- Plot-based forced romance (understandable, please offer more options in the future!) however it's a nice excuse to include Sunrider's first H scene so I'll let it go this time.
- Minimal amount of side quests (they can't really be called side quests anyway, since they're important to the plot), but hopefully this will be fixed in future updates. I think if there were more it would fix the difficulty issues as well, and it could offer opportunities for more meaningful choices.

Other than that, great work, Love in Space. I look forward to updates on this game. Please don't ruin this opportunity. I will continue being a $20 patron, so I expect more great work! Seriously, the story was so much better than I expected in this update, just continue with what you're doing and you're golden.


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FULL REVIEW

OVERVIEWSunrider: Liberation Day is the sequel to Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius (or just Sunrider), which is a free game offered here on Steam. Sunrider Academy is also on steam, but it's a spinoff prequel to the original, isn't canon, and doesn't include all the characters of the original game. Skip to the bottom for a quick summary. Don't let my playtime fool you, I've been playing betas of this game for a long time now via Love in Space's Patreon.

WHAT'S DIFFERENTLiberation Day is a very good sequel compared to the original. As one of the Patreon backers, I was able to follow this project from beginning to end. I must say it's been improved a lot. The battle mechanics, which were the main issue in the original game, have been improved. The graphics and animations have been improved. There's also a wider variety of music, and even a great OP.

However, keep in mind that unlike the original game, the characters in this game are voiced in Japanese ONLY. The original Sunrider had only English VAs, but due to the R18 content in this game (if you get the Denpasoft edition mod http://steamcommunity.com/app/358750/discussions/0/405693392916238299/ ) they had to get professional Japanese VAs. This was also due in part to their stretch goal being reached on Patreon, where they said they'd get professional Japanese VAs for the game, as well as a great opening animation. They really have delivered.
EDIT: Thanks to the v2.0 update, it's now possible to enable MoA battle voices, and to disable story voices, so it's more similar to the original game.

IMPORTANT NOTEI *HIGHLY* recommend you play the original game first, otherwise you'll have no idea what's going on in this one. And you might as well, since it's free and only takes a couple hours to complete. The story is great, you make important choices, and it introduces you to all the different characters. And best of all, you can import your save from the old game into this one. If you copy your persistent save file from Mask of Arcadius(game/saves/persistent) into the same directory as Liberation Day, you will be able to import your choices from the original game when you hit Start. Sunrider is extremely plot-driven and there will be many battles. It's not all about the cute girls, so if you're looking for a cheap, quick eroge, look elsewhere.

BATTLESAs for the battles themselves, it's a turn-based strategy game. You place your units (Ryders and ships) at the left, and the enemy approaches from the right (and sometimes other directions depending on the situation). Each unit has different strengths and weaknesses and has a variety of skills and other weapons to use. Some may be better for close range combat and travel fast, and others may be slow but hard hitting, for example. There's many strategic possibilities and you can choose how to level up your crew, as well as your ship (the Sunrider) itself. I don't want to spoil every mechanic of the game, but you get the general idea.

<I removed some content here from my original review since it was taking up space I needed for the update above>

SUMMARY / TL/DRSolid combat. Great music and art. Choices matter. Play the original first to know what you're getting into: http://store.steampowered.com/app/313730/ Access H scenes with http://steamcommunity.com/app/358750/discussions/0/405693392916238299/ Lots of cute girls.

SHOULD YOU BUY?If you liked the original Sunrider, definitely! Just don't forget to import your save from the original.
Copy your persistent save file from Mask of Arcadius (game/saves/persistent) into the same directory as Liberation Day. You can then import your choices from the original game when you hit Start.

Alright first I like to mention beware of spoilers when reading this for while I shall try to use spoilers tags but I may still drop one or two minor spoilers here or there in this review. Thank you.

Moving on.

Originally, I played through this game and was quite enjoying it. The Japanese VAs were at first gratting but once the game picked up I started to like them. As for the Linear Storyline, I wasn't all that happy about it for I am a fan of Chiraga therefore didn't really mind it all that much. The game play itself was still similar to the other games in the series but adds some new stuff like Paladin's draw fire command, and the new mercenaries added to the game. This resulted in larger battles which where quite interesting.

Then came the ending, and I just couldn't not believe what had happened. I was upset and angry at it like many others I am sure. I kind of figured there would be another game after this thanks to the TBC banner. But still the ending just was punch in the gut. One that I did not see coming. I get that Love In Space wanted a Cliffhanger that would bring in more players for the next half of the series. I understand that. But that wasn't the way to do a cliffhanger. As a writer and reader of fanfiction myself doing a cliffhanger like that often ends up with many readers dropping the story all together.

A few hours after I beat the game I calmed down to look at the ending without being upset and I wondered what the next game would bring with the main ship and character dead. Finally Samu-kun announced the 2.0 update. I was at first was like it wasn't going to change much at all. Therefore wasn't expecting much to change when I played through the game a second time with the 2.0 update added. I may have missed a few of the new changes made to the story line as I was just breezing through the game to get to the ending to see what changes where made.

Finally the ending started. At first I was like okay no real changes then the music changed and the missing two Ryders of the Sunrider Team show up to save the day. I was cheering like crazy, pumping my fist in celebration. But the Sunrider was still destroyed and my mood dropped like a rock wondering what was going to happen now. Then we see Kayto being saved by the Prototype Lynn. And I let out the breath that I did not know I was holding. I was like okay the Sunrider is destroyed, but the majority of the cast are okay, with only two dead. Then WHAM. Hello Claude I thought you were dead! My mood start soaring. Especially when it was mentioned that Chigara maybe still alive as well. I was like alright things are looking up. Then we get a peak into the second phase of the Neutral Rim War. While the Sunrider Crew gather themselves after the diaster that was Second Battle of Cera. The crew split up to prepare themselves for the next stage of the war. Then we get the same after-credit scene that the original ending had. Which makes things far more interesting. Though I do admit the ghost!Chigara scene freaked me out.

Alright for those who haven't played the 2.0 update yet I recommend you do not read thoe above spoilers. For it will spoil the entire game. That said here is brief list on the pros and cons of Liberation day for me like other reviews.

PRO
Awesome new Soundtrack
New Add Ons Make the Game Far Better
The Japanese VA while at first not that good gets better as the game goes on
The Storyline
CON
Game was Too Short. Could have been longer.
The choice to change VA to English in the 2.0 Update is a bit out of synce of sorts with the rest of the game which is still Japanese
Could have done VA for some of the mercenary units like in the other games. Only a few lines would have been good.
The Japanese In-Battle Chatter could have gotten subtitles or something.

reviewText:
I don't usually write reviews (ever) but I felt compelled this time to write one as I saw that most reviews are from people that played V1.0 before V2.0. I (intentionally) didn't play V1.0, so here is my opinion only based on V2.0. I didn't really bother with spoilers tag as most of this is already heavy with spoilers. I tried to avoid major spoilers but minor to moderate spoilers are not hid in this review. You have been warned. Also, for spoilerless conclusion, or for TL;DR look at the last paragraph. So without further ado my personal take on Sunrider: Libartion Day:

Short. Very short. At Captain difficulty it only took a little more than five and a half hour. For the price right now that's unacceptable especially after MoA and Academy.
The characters are... fine, I guess? I personally didn't really like how their personalities developed or declined in some cases. Sola has just a little more personality than her Seraphim until the very end where she gets a little time to shine, and I mean little. About a minute or two and that's it. Asaga and Ava have no defining character trait except jealousy for the majority of the game. Icari and Kryska could be furniture for all they add to the story. They bond somewhat with each other which I liked, but that's all. Claude is completely sidelined too until the last half an hour or so. Chigara as main love interest is an interesting idea which I personally would've liked but the romance is forced and basically just a plot device just as Ava and Asagas jealousy. All in all the charaters are just clichés, cardboard cutouts (and not from the good kind) and their interpersonal relationships are astonishingly poor at most cases. Which is a complete and utter shame as we saw in Sunrider Academy and even in MoA that they could be so much more. I mean if you could write your characters to be interesting in a slice-of-life how could you make them so uninteresting in a mecha-space setting, I have no idea. As for the supporting cast: they are there. Adm. Grey gives what you expect while Veniczar Fabulous Fontana doesn't really have any role until the end, and Cosette if alive is downplayed, forgotten in the brig until the very last fight. How can I be that critical of the characters but still say that they're fine? I'm a character guy, I'm very character conscious in my games where this aspect is expected which means anything below top-notch I'll slander without remorse.
In terms of story the game gives you what you expect with some good twists and turns. It's not a masterpiece but it's well done and enjoyable. A shame it's so short. The ending doesn't work in it's favor either because albeit enjoyable and emotional (well, for me at least) it's rushed. It can be excused (I quite like the ending actually) but it doesn't change the facts. What I expected, didn't get much, and realize that I didn't get much just after I finished it: humor. MoA and Academy was witty, used the situations and characters to it's full extent in terms of humorous situations, eased into and flow well with drama. And despite that a good 3/4 of the game would be ideal for good jokes what we get is: Icari is tsundere. Claude is useless. And pretty much that's it. There are still some good jokes (which I'll not spoil) but mostly the game plays seriously. I mean come on if you force the jealousy thing at least give us some well thought out jokes every now and then about it. You wanted to us to take things seriously, okay, I get it but if you could do that in MoA and even in Academy to some extent all the while keeping the humor why not here?
The battle mechanic (on the surface what I saw at least) didn't really change since MoA although there are some minor changes here and there. It's serviceable but not exceptionally good or bad. Firing the Vanguard cannon is still a thrill and it even got a little animation. If you don't like Japanese VO in battles you change to the MoA voices. But the engine (which is Ren'py if I'm not mistaken) seems to be pushed to limit and slows the game in bigger battles (under an i7, GTX980 and SSD so I don't think my rig is the problem here). But that was a problem in MoA too sometimes so as I said didn't really change. That's about that.
I didn't encounter bugs through my playthrough either small or big ones, the game seems pretty stable (except for the aforementioned slowing in battles).

In conculsion the game feels like that it's just a link, a connection between MoA and the next game. It feels like what it was intended to be early in develpoment: the third part of the free Sunrider series. But they changed the name from Rebirth of the Holy Empire (although the title drop is still there) to Liberation Day and sold it as a new game. As an extention of MoA I'd say it's pretty good, but as a seperate game it lacks the lenght, the depth, and charaters (grr) to actually warrant a separate game. And after the beatdown I give this game why is it still a recommendation? Well, first of all, it's a recommendation with conditions: if you're a fan of Sunrider you'll get your game, flawed but still (if you didn't buy it already). If you just liked the Mask of Arcadius and/or Academy wait for a sale otherwise you'll be most likely dissapointed to some extent. Second: it's still Sunrider, even flawed as it is I just can't hate on it for long for one misstep. I just hope that the next game will be a step forward not backward, because that would really be inexcusable in hindsight.

reviewText:
Drama, intense combat action, love, loss, and humor are blended together well in this visual novel meets tactical combat game, the third in the Sunrider series by the Love In Space crew.

Great writing, voice acting, interesting and likeable characters, and art as always. Decision making is still here along with a seamless importing of how you played Mask of Arcadius.

Some nice improvements as well: there's a new pop-up menu before each battle to give you an opportunity to buy supplies or improve your ships and mechs in case you forgot to do so. The command point problem of the last two games has also been fixed, allowing you to now earn points ~during~ battle by destroying enemies; which makes tactics matter and makes sense from a realism perspective, since a good commander would inspire morale and be more effective. Another positive change is that the Vanguard canon now has unlimited range, which also makes sense since it uses technology that seems similar to Sola's rifle.

Personal observation: with four games under their belts and some of the best writing I've ever experienced in a game, I believe that Love In Space is ready to graduate from Python powered VNs to making a full length JRPG for console (on par with Omega Quintet, for example).

reviewText:
I'm going to split this review into two sections. First, for what came out on release day and second what came out in the V2.00 update.

V1.00:

I supported Liberation Day for a while prior to its release, so it should go without saying that I am biased in favour of this game. When it finally came out, I played it immediately and after completing V1.00 I was in a state of confused anticipation. The game plays out fairly slowly for the most part plot-wise, and then suddenly it all kicks off at the end! Such plot twists! Such action! Before I go on for ages about it, I'll summarise.

Pros:
>Music. The composer did a darn good job on this one, and at least three of these tracks are series favourites. I love a good tune, and this game has some. :D
>Gameplay. While some people miss the old combat animations, I think that Liberation Day runs much smoother without them, and means that missions don't drag on for an eternity. The inclusion of number keys for abilities also make it a lot easier to perform actions.

Cons:
>Price:Length. As stated in most of these reviews, the ratio was a bit too extreme at the start. Even I was looking at it warily after completion wondering if it would have been worth the purchase.
>The route selection is practically done for you in V1. Not wanted, thank you very much. I'll choose my own waifus.

Ultimately it comes down to what you play it for. If, like me, you just wanted to find out what happens next, use the new battle mechanics etc., then I'd say go for it. If you're a little skeptical, then wait for a sale. This game is worth playing, but perhaps not at that price.

Such would my first review have gone, but then V2.00 came along...

I've just completed it and the difference is astronomical in the ending. As well as the restoration of the english voices in battle with new phrases and the ship and galaxy maps, a bucketload of new VN content was slapped onto the end. It improves the cliffhanger tenfold, provides a better resolution than the original, gives us the confessions we wanted all along and sets us up for a really interesting sequel. After completing this end, I was so much more hyped than the first time around.

Price-wise, version 1 was worth (in my opinion) £10-£12 with no reasonable objections. With the patch included, I'd say that has gone up to at least £15-£17 if not more, detracting considerably from the aforementioned con". While it still doesn't quite match the asking price

reviewText:
Although I give the game a thumbs up, there are a lot of asterisks associated with it, so please read through the full review before deciding whether or not you want to purchase the game.

First off, if you haven't played the previous Sunrider games (which are free), don't even bother getting this one until you have. The game throws you right into the middle of things, and nothing about it will make sense if you haven't played the previous games.

Second off, I wouldn't get the game at the current price. It's simply too short to be worth 20 bucks or more. It's worth at most about 10 dollars. Now, if buying this game gets you free access to future titles or free DLC for this chapter, I might change my mind, but as it currently stands, this game isn't even close to worth 20 bucks. I feel like the current price point might be the creators' way of trying to make the money they didn't get from the first two games, since they released them for free. So be warned, if you spend the full price (or the barely-discounted launch price), after you finish the game you will feel like you didn't get your money's worth. I feel like the mixed reaction this game is already getting will lead to the price eventually being lowered to a more appropriate level, so I would wait until that happens if you're interested in purchasing this game.

Now, to get into the game itself. There are both some positives and negatives compared to the previous games in the series. One huge positive is a much-improved research and purchasing system. Researching upgrades for the Sunrider and its Ryders now use intel, which is earned during battles. You can still purchase things from the mining union using money, which is also still earned from battle. So now you can focus on improving both your individual ryders and strengthening your fleet as a whole, whereas in previous games you had to focus on mainly one or the other. It may not sound like much, but it made the game much more enjoyable, and also helped me to customize things to my overall strategy much better than I was able to in the previous games. Music was also a positive, as it was fairly solid throughout the game and really ramped up in a big way at the end. Some of the animations are a little different than in previous games, but once I got used to it I found the visual aesthetics of the game to be solid enough.

Now, for some of the negatives. Choice has been almost entirely removed in this game. Aside from a couple choices, the game is frustratingly linear. When doing side missions, you don't pick and choose. You do them all in order, with no warning. You have almost no control over the plot of the game either. It heads in one direction and one direction only, and there's not a single thing you can do to change that. The first two games built such a wonderful universe that both enthralled the player and reacted to the choices the player made, to make for a rich, dynamic experience. This game just drags the player into increasingly dark places, almost against your will. The previous games had all sorts of thought-provoking philosophical ideas for the player to consider. This game doesn't do that, it just makes you angry.  It feels like instead of trying to be thought-provoking and nuanced like the previous games, the creators decided to forsake all of that in order to be as dark as possible. It's not even a nuanced kind of dark, it's just a shallow, over-exagerrated kind of dark. It's okay to not have a 100% happy ending, but this game doesn't even give you a nuanced path to the dark ending. Now there will be another game, but it's not clear at this time whether it will involve the same characters we've grown to love. If it does indeed feature new, different characters, then the story and ending of this game will have been a colossal mistake. It's not just that this ending is dark, it's that it's not particularly well done at all. It's not well-thought out, reasoned, or nuanced. It's honestly not of the quality of storywriting that I've come to expect from this studio. So if the next game will feature the same characters and provide more nuanced writing and expound on their stories, this game's writing could redeem itself. If not, then this game's story and writing will have been a major letdown, especially towards the end.

Another negative is that the game really bogs down towards the end. Once you're about 75% of the way through the game, it ceases to be fun or enjoyable and turns into an arduous task you have to trudge through to get to the end. It's just one fight after another against massive overpowered enemies. You get a victory screen in one battle, have a few cutscenes, and then get thrown right back into another battle against an even more massive and overpowered enemy fleet. And it repeats this cycle several times. Battles cease to be enjoyable and become something unpleasant you try to get over as quickly as possible so you can progress the story. This is due to two different flaws combining. One is that the pacing is really poor for the last quarter of the game. Too many massive battles in quick succession. The other is a flaw in the design of the enemy armies in the last several battles. They're just too big, and receive too many reinforcements each turn. It was okay to face that kind of thing once, but after that it just becomes frustrating and arduous to deal with. Even compared to the previous games, enemy fleet size gets really out of hand during the last several battles in this game. It gets to a point where it's not even enjoyable to defeat the enemies, it's just a pointlessly long chore to get through.

As far as the quality of the game goes, it's not bad. There were a few minor typos and I did get a error that crashed the game once, but I was able to just reload a quicksave and then got through the point with no issues. A few minor bugs are to be expected at launch from a small studio, so I wouldn't count it as a negative. It doesn't impact the game much at all, and I'm sure they'll get fixed soon anyways.

So overall, I do still give this game a thumbs up. If you really enjoyed the previous Sunrider games you won't be satisfied with never playing this one, so if you liked those games, I would eventually get this one once the price is about half of what it currently is, or maybe even wait until it's a little lower than that. The game does have solid enough storywritng for a large chunk of it, it's just the complete lack of choice overall and the turn towards poorly-written over-exagerrated darkness in the last quarter of the game that drags it down some. If the developers read this, my plea to you would be to make the story less linear overall, and especially to completely re-write the last 25% of the story to make it more nuanced. The darker overall tone of the game is fine, it's the fact that the player is forced down one concrete path that devolves into absolute hell that makes the story and ending of this game so unsatisfying. So yes, I do barely recommend this game as it's a great series overall and this game has many of those great elements, as well as introducing some great new elements too. But it's simply not worth the current price, and there are some major letdowns with the writing and story overall that the previous games don't really have, at least not to this degree, as well as a distinct lack of choices (especially meaningful ones) compared to the previous games. It's still a decent game overall, it's just not quite as good as I was expecting from the first paid game in a great series, and especially not what I was expecting for $23. Quite simply, I was expecting something that was at least an A minus, and what I got was something that was more in the range of C plus/ B minus. Still a passing score and slightly better than the average, which is why I give the game a thumbs up, just not what I was expecting out of the game and not enough content to justify the current price.

reviewText:
Ok before I get into the review, I have to say this; the initial release of the game was really upsetting, BUT loveinspace listened to their fans and quickly updated the game with more content and better story. You have to give them credit for caring.
The initial release was awfull, but I'm happy to say they fixed it up nicely. The Sunrider series is one of my favourites and this continuation gets my hyped for the next installment. If you havn't played the original Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius then I highly recomend it, it's free on steam!

PROS:
-Great Graphics, impovement over MoA
-Great Vocals, can toggle between english and japanese
-One of my favourite strategic combat systems, vary occasionally crashes when combat starts but it always offers a quicksave just before combat. And lets face it; if you don't save before combat then anything that happens afterwards is your own fault.
-Great Sci-Fi story, PLAY MoA FIRST!
-Your spaceship is a badass cross between a space-battleship and a space-aircraft carrier, only the aircraft are giant robots. On top of that, the entire ship is basically a giant space laser cannon of death. It's like the death-star laser, only on a ship not a metal moon.
-Foreshadows an AMAZING sequel.
-You get closer to the pilots in this game, theres more cooperative character development and the devs have confirmed we will get different romantic routes in future installments.

CONS
-Kinda short for 25 bucks, MoA is completely free and still longer than this, It's worth it if you really like this series though.
-No routes yet. (confirmed in future installments however)
-Vary occasionally crashes when combat starts but it always offers a quicksave just before combat. And lets face it; if you don't save before combat then anything that happens afterwards is your own fault.

Note:
Something everyone was complaining about, despite clearly having a harem you are forced into a (TEMPORARY) romantic relationship with Chigara. Now I don't DISLIKE her, I doubt anyone does, BUT I have no romantic fealing towards her whatsoever. PLEASE NOTE: The devs have said that we WILL get to choose the route we want! We will NOT be locked into a perminent relationship with Chigara, but I assume it's still available if anyones into loli. Wasn't sure where to put this, it started as a CON, but turned into kind of a PRO, it's good to know that the devs have basically said we WILL get the ending we want.

Another note:
There was originally way more CONS, but I feel the V2.0 update fixed them! YAY!

Conclusion:
You need to understand that I wouldn't have recommended this game when it was first released, there was less content, and various other annoying things, but loveinspace listened to their fans and put in the effort to make the game better, thats an amazing thing to be able to say about the developers. They released V2.0 and I played through it again, and I can honestly say that my opinion has changed after greatly enjoying it. Also keep in mind that some reviews you may read were written before the V2.0 update, I urge you to give V2.0 reviews priority over V1.0 reviews.

If you enjoyed MoA, then you will enjoy Liberation Day, it's a bit pricey but if you can afford it and liked MoA then please consider buying it.
If you havn't played MoA, then download it right now, it's free, on steam, and everyone loves it.

Sunrider: Liberation Day
A game I have been waiting a long time for and I'm not disappointed of what I got. The game continues the story directly where Mask of Arcadius ended. The battles, the music, the good looking art (even better than before), the new japanese voice actors (which I personally love!) and the great story continue our adventure through this great galaxy.

With the V2.0 added to the game they brought back some of the things from the previous games like the english voice actors, even more story content for the ending of Liberation day (which clears a lot of open questions and makes the ending more understandable) and also the restored ship and galaxy map.

For the price: I see lots of reviews saying that the price is too high for such a short story. I personally think it's okay because I have played the previous games and they were around the same playtime (8-10 hours) depending on if you just rush through the battles or try them on a normal/higher difficulty. If you think it's still too much then you can wait for a discount, it will come sooner or later.

Before I end my review here with an  absolutely recommendation  for the game there's one very  Important  thing to say: This is  not  the final end and story of Sunrider, there will be more installments coming and therefore I hope you give the whole Sunrider Series a chance because you won't get disappointed!

Well, what to say to the game? I played it in one go last night and i must say i am not that impressed. The game was overall a bit too short, the story felt a bit weird, you cant make any choices (like for Sidequests or Conversation Choices), it feels like you are getting grabbed by the hand and are just being pulled through the story. there are some good aspects, like the whole Traitor Hunt, but it wasnt enough made out of it. reviewText:
Some spoilers follow in this quick review.

If you enjoyed the first game for the combat and story, then you'll like this one as well.  The combat has been changed up with some new features and removal of some old ones.  There are new units, like gunships that work well against ryders, AOE attacks, unlimited Vanguard range, and CP changes to consider.  CP is capped at 5000, but you gain more in combat for each destroyed enemy.  Something taken out is the close-up animation of attack results.  All combat animations and damage results are now displayed on the battle map.  That means you do lose some information like how much damage was blocked by armor or shields and how many missiles actually hit.  Gravity abilities on some units now work on capital ships as well, so you can line up some awesome Vanguard shots.  Speaking of which, there is a cool new animation for firing the cannon now.

The story pretty much picks up right where MoA left off.  The PACT fleet is defeated, Sunrider is heavily damaged, and the war will soon be at an end.  The clones are now the real enemies with Fontana and much of the rest of PACT wanting peace.  There is only going to be one love interest for Captain Shields and that is Chigara.  It seems a little odd if you've been trying to woo any of the other women in the last game; because everyone seems to be under the impression that you've been interested in her all along.  This does bring out some jealousy among some of the crew, and that'll cause trouble down the road.  The effects of jealousy and unconditional love are explored, as well as how those can be used to help or harm.  The story is linear and about as long as the first release of Sunrider; ending after the outcome of the battle of Cera.

The ship and galaxy map are gone, but it seems the next big update is going to patch them in along with some extra ending story content.  The option to visit the store, buy upgrades, or save are now automatically presented before each battle.  At this time there are only Japanese voiceovers, and the music continues to impress.

I feel 50/50 about Liberation Day *Spoilers*

On one side, I like. On the same token, I dislike it. I like the new music, the new art in the game was very polished, and overall the story was nice until the end. The story had me on the edge of my seat and did leave me wanting more and got me worried about events that might happen. Claude's death felt very cop out and I wasn't very happy about that. Out of everything that was happening on the battlefield, and positions one holds on a ship, (I'm looking at you radar guy) somehow in all that she got killed in a way that felt cheap. All those wtf events that happened at the end... Like come on man. Really? I'm all for cliffhanger ends to get someone to think about past events, and theory craft for future installments, but thats too much. Too many cooks spoil the broth so to speak. So much happened at the end that the emotion of the scene fell upon dull emotions. I didn't feel anything, and I felt like I was supposed to feel something. But so much was going and constantly changing so fast you have no time to feel anything, but try to make sense of the events that are transpiring. I'll be honest, and I am sure thats what devs want, feedback of sorts. The writing at the end, it sucked. It didn't pull me in like the rest of the writing in this VN, it didn't leave me wanting more, and the attachment I felt throughout the story was gone at the end. If there is something I can impart from having some writing experience of my own, is don't oversaturate plot points all in one moment. It will leave the reader feeling overwhelmed. LD was rather kinetic and lacked the choices that MOA had. I see the way they wanted to direct the game towards, just wish you had more control over it.

All that aside, I would say I really enjoyed it, but due to the nature of the events at the end, I give this game a 7/10, which is not bad. Also since Sunrider is a game about multiple parallel universes and time travel, I don't even wanna start theory crafting, like nope. In the end, I still have the Wishall, and I don't know how that will affect events in the fourth game, if at all. I feel more like Time Travel will play a huge role in the next game with going back to the past as a certain character to try to change events for the better. Considering someone came from the future at the end of LD. Also that end cg is puzzling with that quote it had. Needless to say, I hope the next Sunrider is longer than this one.

To all you guys and gals out there, I await to see speculation posts pop up. I will probably replay this to get the final cgs, and replay Sunrider Academy a bit to try to find more evidence. Cause really I doubt this will be the end of Claude, Chigara, or anyone else that carries an affection score.
