Some of you may have noticed the negative feedback from this game's initial launch. However, now version 2.0 has been released (available via beta opt in) and it radically changes my review of this game. I would urge everyone to consider newer reviews or edited reviews with greater weight than old ones.

The combat is functional and tight, the mechanics are easy to learn but can be difficult to master, presenting the player with a challange at the medium difficulty levels and there has been significant rebalancing since the last full release game. Combat is often tense but not truly unfair.

The art work is wonderful, full voice overs in Japanese and partial voice overs in English are very well done and the music is first rate. Even without understanding the words the main theme is highly kinetic. The art work, and particularly facial expressions, really convey tone and subtle meaning.

The majority of the game as of the time of writing is quite linear, and long time fans will know that this series is used to giving us choice and room to move. This can come across as jarring and even agrevating as our protagonist is forced into choices we would not have him make. However, the v2.0 update changes everything. Stick with it and you will be rewarded. Choice and agency return in the v2.0 editions and the pay off is well worth the wait. There are new and interesting major plot developments and key personal moments.

I can now say this with confidence to newcommers and old fans alike. I recomend this game. V2.0 fixes a great deal. To newcommers I would also recomend picking up Mask of Arcadius (the direct prequel) it should still be free and will make this a much richer story for you. You may also wish to consider the Academy spin off. Give this game a go!

reviewText:
There has been a lot of controversy about this game, but seeing how there are still a number of people reviewing it positively I blame much of it on the fact that crowdfunding raises expectations and likewise the disappointment if they are not fulfilled.

My experience may also differ here because I never played any of the betas, even though I had access to them via patreon. It does wonders for reducing hype.^^

Actually, a few more months of development would have done good, of course you can never prevent all glitches and it was more stable for me than the previous games. No idea at which patch, but I came across the series after Mask of Arcadius was already released.

My main gripe is the comparative linearity, though I can see why the development team felt that was necessary. But even if a certain plot thread had to be linear, there were other ways to accomplish much the same emotional impact and retain many of the conversations (this is a considerable cost factor) while giving the player more freedom than this had, though there some scenes I have not seen, judging by the empty CG slots. However, character interaction was too scarce for my liking, which was also understandable but is still not appreciated.

This is not even a complaint about eroge narrative conventions or any one character being particularly misportrayed or underrepresented as some people may feel, since I don't consider this an eroge, and it works quite well as a VN. It doesn't even deserve the 18+ tag in my opinion (yes, with the patch and all) because it's just a story that has some sex in it. Which is a little graphic. Change one or two angles minimally and this is completely tame. There are plenty of books and TV series that are much more graphic, and aren't at all marketed with that. It's hardly ever even mentioned in any sort of commentary or coverage. Take Ken Follet's The Pillars of Earth, for example, which even has graphic assault. Perhaps people are more sensitive about pictures, but pictures of much harsher things are so easy to come by nowadays, and you see much of the same in sex education at schools, the label becomes a farce. Which makes me rant. This is a filibuster though, not really anything to do with the game and the reviewer criticism wouldn't much change either way, except perhaps in tone.

However, having played the previous games, I would retroactively buy this one at the price above, and I probably would even if I hadn't played it yet, just because the first two parts, over 30 hours of playtime for me, are free and would even be worth the price of a full game to me, though I doubt they'd find terribly many buyers that way. XD

And finally: The ending is good. Though I also liked the original ending of the Mass Effect trilogy, so maybe that is not for you. Also, it isn't the ending of the series, and will not even stay the ending of this game (the latter feels like a bit off a loss, since the impact is just right like this). Still, the developer is doing their best to meet the criticism: http://steamcommunity.com/games/358750/announcements/detail/955132547461863264

reviewText:
Gameplay:
This is a mix of a visual novel and turn based tactics / strategy (similar to Fire Emblem). I can't emphazise this enough: it's not just a VN, more than half of the game consist of the turn-based combat.


Difficulty:
The difficulty of this game is very high, even though it may appeal as some generic VN. Everyone who was shocked by the previous game's difficulty can rest assured: the balancing is much better than in the previous one. You'll propably still die a lot during your first playthrough, but it never feels unfair.


Story (there will be a few spoilers but nothing critical):
The game starts exactly where the last one ended. The story has two main aspects: one being the war against PACT to free Cera, another one being the search for a traitor. There are some obvious candidates for the traitor, but in the end I'm still not sure who actually betrayed whom. Either everyone betrayed everyone or no one betrayed anyone. Additionally there's a forced romance which is important to the story's end and propably also the start of the next game.


My review:
Most people complain about the game's playtime and the forced romance in the story.

Regarding the playtime: when you're playing on medium difficulty you'll propably need around 10 hours. That people who rush through the game only need 5 hours or less is only natural. As I said in the beginning: this isn't just a VN, half of it is tactical battles. If miss half of the game it's self evident that you only need half the time to finish.

Regarding the forced romance: Personally I don't have a problem with the forced romance and neither with the choiceof character the devs made. The actual problem is the pacing of the game's story. I think it's just a few weeks of in-game time and because of that the romance feels very rushed and quite unnatural.


The short version of all this: the turn-based battles are challanging and for me even the main appeal of the game. The story has a small problem with it's pacing but is still very enjoyable.

reviewText:
Gotta say. While Mask of Arcadius kept me on my seat, Liberation Day made me almost miss work. Twice.

It was a neat little sequel that honestly felt a little rushed when compared to it's predecessor in terms of pace. I get that this chapter is focusing more on the story than the combat, which I'm sure a lot of people appreciated considering how long someone can spend on a single battle, especially if they save scum like me in order to make every shot count. I understand that the majority of the war had already been fought out in the first game, but the buildup between the first fight and the final boss just didn't feel satisfying. I'm just kinda dissapointed that there wasn't a little more meat in between those two points as far as combat goes. A couple more optional sidequests would have helped significantly. The fact that they would be optional would be perfect, because the people who are just in it for the story wouldn't have to deal with them. The combat system is honestly half of the reason I love this game series so far, so I did feel it didn't recieve as much love as it could have.

A few neat points is that the options in the first game actually have an effect on this one. One of the most important one I feel being whether or not you commanded Ava to fire the Vanguard or not. (Then again, that could just be because Ava is my BEST GRILL) For one, it felt a lot more rewarding considering how long I had to wait to find out what happened to her. Secondly, the scene where they reunite is a lot ♥♥♥♥ing cuter when you did order her, plus you got her wearing that cute little eye patch the rest of the game. (RIP Ava's depth perception) The others I feel, didn't have as strong an impression, seeing as they don't actually dictate which girl you have the most browny points with. Then again, lets get real. ALL of'em want the Kayto ♥♥♥♥, minus maybe Kryska and Cosette.

This brings me to my next point. The forced romance... God, this made me SO pis-sed. Honestly, even though Chigara was one of my top three favorites in the first game, as well as Asaga, I came to sort of hate them both as the game went on. The further I got into the story, the more Chigara didn't seem like the Chigara I fell for in the first game. And Asaga. *sigh* Might as well change her name to Asuka cause of how bit-chy she became. The only thing I can say made up for the forced romance was the ending. Blew my ♥♥♥♥ing mind. It made me forgive everything I didn't like about the storyline and I can't wait for what happens next. I still hate Asaga though. And I'm sorta confused what my feelings towards Chigara are. Claude too, now that I think about it...

Anyways. Great game. Can't wait for the next release~ B]

reviewText:
An adventure with Mechas, betrayal and... who forgot the space whales??1 1/2 years. One and a half yars we've been waiting for the conclusion of the adventures of the Sunrider. Was the wait worth it?? short answer: yes. Long answer: yeeeeeeees.

ok, but now seriously:
Sunrider: Liberation Day is set right after Mask of Arcadius. To be precise, it starts off right when Fontana shot (one of the many) Arcadius at the end of MoA . The battle against PACT is won, their old leader gone and now it's time to liberate Cera, Kayto's homeplanet. before doing so, he (who still doesn't have a voice, safe for his very energetic 'FIRE', lol) and Admiral Grey meet onboard the Core, which they had gotten access to. They discuss their future plans, what to do with the core and also get a peace treaty (too high of a word, but eh.) with Fontana, the new PACT leader, done.
All that's left before setting course for Cera is to fix up the Sunrider and interrogate the captured Cosette and 'Arcadius'.
While the former doesn't contribute anything helpful, the interrogation of the Arcadius-clone gives them some knowledge about the 'Prototypes' as they're really called and about how Chigara is also one of them. This sparks some distrust towards Chigara under some of the Sunrider's crew, especcially Asaga, who is having a hard time dealing with the situation as she wants to protect the Sunrider and Kayto in particular by all means necessary.
After the interrogation, the crew tries their best to get the repairs done as quickly as possible, but when an ambushing PACT fleet that has hidden itself in an ion storm attacks them, they are forced to enter the first 'real' battle with a bit of a handycap.

As I entered the first battle, I immediately noticed some severe improvements over the combat of FA and MoA:
1) Icari and Kryska are no longer next to useless. Kryska can now pull enemy fire onto her and simultaniously increase her armor while Icari's stealth now makes her WAY less likely to get targeted by the enemy.
2) Battles no longer have several pictures for every attack, attacks now happen on the overmap no matter what. This really improves the flow of the battle.
3) There are many, MANY more ships per battle than previously. You now have ~ 2-3 times as many ships as in the first two games and the enemy has... honestly, it's hard to tell how many more they have, since they always had a ♥♥♥♥♥on of them. With the addition of these ships, it really has more of a feel of a battlefield and you are less reliant on the RNG-gods to be on your side (which they weren't).
There are also several changes to the commands: you can now order multiple of them per round, the command points now cap out at 4000 (can be upgraded to 5000) and charge up by destroying individual ships, the vanguard cannon now costs 4000 points but has unlimited range and the costs for short range warps increase when used several times in quick succession.

After this battle (which took over an hour to complete... I was deeply impressed), the Sunrider and the Alliance set course for Cera to liberate it and to defeat the Prototypes, which have taken over the control over many PACT ships.

Now... I won't go into detail here (for obvious reasons), but I want to say that the last... let's say 15-20 minutes had as jarring a shift of tone as I've seen in a long time. Just when I had thought that all had ended well, the fake credits stopped and made room for a really f'ed up after story. When the REAL credits then rolled, it took me quite some time to fully comprehend what the hell I had just witnessed. The only comfort I can find for myself is that my favorite characters, Asaga (I think I'm the only one in the Asaga fanclub now... yay ;-;) and Sola, survived.

I have to say though, there aren't just positive things I can say about Sunrider: Liberation Day.
For one, it's a bit on the shorter side with ~8 hours of gameplay. It's probably my fault for expecting something a bit bigger, but I feel as if I should adress it anyways.
There were also a few things (two of them are bugs/glitches, with the other one I'm not sure what exactly it's classified as) that forced me to reload and in some cases even restart the entire game. For example, the good old 'out of memory' bug/glitch is back, which made me restart the game in two cases. Luckily the Auto-save function works really well :D
Also: there were several times, especcially earlier in the game, where I had to end my turn prematurely because one of the Cera gunships got stuck somewhere in an Assault-attack and I was unable to use ANYTHING until I ended the turn.
Lastly, the battles had a tendancy to lag quite a bit. This is most likely caused by the many units, but more often than not, there would be random timeframes in the enemies turn where absolutely nothing happened, followed by a unit hopping to another square/hexagon/whateveryouwannacallit. This seemed to be happening the most with the Arcadius Ryders, but that might've just been my imagination.

In the end, I have to say that I really love Sunrider: Liberation Day, because it has several severe improvements over the first two games, which I already loved, while keeping the core intact. There were less choices and the Lovestory was with Chigara no matter what happend, but since that was essentially what was to be expected, considering how MoA played out, I didn't mind that too much.
Now, if you'll excuse me, I'll go back to SA to see Asaga and Kayto together again. Because while I really didn't mind how it played out here and feel like anything else would've been just weird, Asaga's still my favorite character in the series by a long shot =w=.

reviewText:
NOTICE: If you are one of the many (like me) that got Mask of Arcadius for free, this review is for you!
There are a TON of negative reviews for this installment, and I can tell you why: Liberation Day isn't free. The price point is going to be an issue right away, because you are paying 25$US for a game that can be completed even on the harder difficulties in about 4 hours. That stings.

BUT, that's about the same length of each of the previous TWO chapters (yes, there were two). Also similarly priced before the free release (from what I've been told).

This episode improves graphically and mechanically over MoA, with the exception of some lag in the battle screen. Kudos all around for Love in Space's commitment to improving their game. The character and unit sprites are better, the new VO is professional, and the new additions to the soundtrack are excellent.

The narrative though, that's the part that's got people up in arms. Ignore the people whining about the ending; cliffhangers are nothing new to games, don't start getting your panties in a wad over it now. The real problem is the EXTREME linearity of this installment. The choices are minimal, the story arc itself has NO deviation, and in spite of the fact that you can import your saves, it feels like none of the previous choices mattered beyond delivering you to the same controversial ending. YOU DO NOT GET TO MARRY YOUR WAIFU IN LIBERATION DAY, regardless of which one you're going for. In fact, it seems like very little of that matters this time around.

My overall impression of Liberation day is positive. It delivers another chapter in an increasingly compelling story, but at the same time it feels as if the story was written into a corner and needed to backpedal but couldn't fight its own momentum. If you like Sunrider, stop griping about the price and for f$ck's sake quit telling people to pirate it.

TL;DR Liberation Day as a strategy game is an improvement over its predecessors in almost every way. On the other hand, the story feels rushed, cut off too abruptly and with so much cheese you'll never crap again. Here's hoping the next installment spends more of its time on the story all these fans are so invested in (myself included).

P.S. I'm currently 120$US into Love in Space's endeavour. I don't regret a single cent.
